FreeResponse: Help is help, and I'm sure people could opt out of either option if they'd like. It could be an informative experiment with long-term benefits.

I think that it was somewhat appropriate because the people were all assigned at random. None of the people were put in an extremely harrowing situation as well.  Also, the director will allow for everyone to have a choice of which option they want to pursue a year after the test is complete.
It's appropriate because it helps those in a poor situation better themselves with a trade.
I have no idea what one has to do with the other.

The choice is not ideal because depending on the outcome of the tests one half of the adults will be at a disadvantage. Those who receiving training immediately may quickly flood the market, or take available jobs leaving the untrained people in a worse situation. However I think the decision is still somewhat appropriate because at least half of the adults will be better off than before.

It's important to research methods to escape poverty. While it's uncommon to practice this particular form of charity, it may be beneficial to see which helps more, a roof or training. Hopefully this test will help streamline charity donations in the future so that less is wasted.

You can think you have the best possible solution to a problem but unless you do an A/B style experiment, how will you really know that you're providing the best that you can? So I think its important what this director is doing.
Despite how effective it is or isn't, it is more important for individuals to learn skills to help themselves.

This is actually a pretty well conceived idea - as to the point being made that basic necessities that are required for survival should be arguably provided or in some way have the resources implemented to the public in which can acquire the essential methods needed to survive.

I think It will give a good idea of the best option. I do worry about those without the good roof though. I think either will be helpful. I would let the individuals first come basis pick what group they wanted to be a part of.
He is testing his idea first, before committing, and overall it will help a significant number of people
because it will help in two different ways

Although I don't really know if there's a statistical correlation or evidence of causation between one's roof and one's poverty level, it seems a little far-fetched, whereas free training in a trade could really help someone get out of poverty. If someone's roof is completely destroyed or very leaky, the roof thing could definitely be a good idea, but if someone simply has a few shingles missing or hasn't had their roof checked in a while, this idea is silly. Also, most people in poverty don't own their own homes, so the roof repairs would most likely benefit landlords instead of poor people - and, as we all know, many landlords are highly exploitative and take advantage of poorer tenants.
The director seems to be running an experiment with people's lives.  They should instead try to incorporate both training and basic housing needs for all families into the solution.
It is better to learn how to fish, than someone doing it for you.
i agree with this statement because why just keep giving money away if it doesn't do any one any good in the long run.
Not all people would be physically able to perform a trade. Also, one month of training would not be sufficient to master a trade and gain employment in that trade.
He's trying to help a struggling nation. And he's experimenting with different ways to help them the most so they can escape poverty
He is trying to optimize the use of funds.
I don‰Ûªt think it‰Ûªs fair for one person to decide who is going to receive what kind of help.  All persons in need should be treated equally and receive the same amount of help.
I thought of how it affected the people involved.
Dealing with human lives is a difficult and complicated task. I'm sure that debates could go on for days concerning the appropriateness of this study.
i dont see how its very fair to choose who gets training and who gets a study roof. what if those people have kids that need to be warm and out of the weather isnt that more important.
Instead of running a study, he could donate the money .
I believe this will prove that the second option works better. Teaching a man to fish is better than giving a man a fish. I applaud the director's efforts to determine this.

It's sorta immoral to test a theory on living people. I think it's rather obvious that training is the better choice, it's unethical to deny that to one group simply to prove a point, especially if they don't know it's happening to them.

The wording may be unclear, but it does not seem like the director is running the experiment on people who are experiencing extreme poverty. So the results may not be the same for people in extreme poverty.
first i doubt there are very many low income families that own their home. Second, a month of "job training" is rather ridiculous. he is assuming alot with that.

I think the director looked at the resources he had available and came up with a viable solution that would help as many people as possible. However, fixing the roof for some of the families does not appear to be a logical solution to helping these families get out of poverty. I am sure the roofs do need to be fixed, but giving the adults in the families training or jobs would be more beneficial.
i think he is wasting his time and donations because neither choice is going to be of much help

People in need have not consented to being apart of an experiment; neither did the people who donated money consent to having their money used for experimentation. Experiments should be done under proper settings with people who agree to be participants and with money earmarked for that purpose.
It seems perfectly reasonable to conduct his own personal trial on the drugs.
The patients should be aware of his study, and should have the right to choose which medication they are going to be using.
It makes sense because medications can have varying levels of effectiveness. The doctor made a sound decision because all patients should have the best outcomes, in regards to medicine.

AS A PATIENT, I DON'T LIKE BEING USED AS A TEST SUBJECT, BUT THE DOCTOR DOES NOT SEEM TO HAVE VERY CLEAR INFORMATION TO WORK FROM AND NEEDS A WAY TO MAKE HIS OWN DETERMINATION, AND SINCE BOTH HAVE PRIOR APPROVAL THIS SEEMS LIKE A POTENTIALLY REASONABLE APPROACH.

Because at that phase it isn't moral or ethical to test medications on humans.  They all deserve the chance to be well and healthy, and the ones getting the medication that doesn't "work" as well doesn't deserve the best options.
If both are intended and suspected to be effective with no major unforeseen side effects, it's entirely fair to do this.

Well the drugs could  have better results for some people and worst results for other, so taking two groups of 50 and giving 1 type each and seeing which is better is a bad idea in my opinion. Because one drug could be better for a certain type of person and worst so instead of finding which drug is better for the average person he should find out which drug is better for all different types of people.
There was no additional risk to either patient set, he could have done either acceptable.
The item maybe of best used by many people.

The test pool he has is most likely not diverse enough to get a good idea of which one works overall on the most people, there are too many things outside his influence that could factor the outcome. It also makes him think of his patients less as individuals, which could lead to a bad judgement for that particular patient
As long as both drugs are accepted by the FDA, it shouldn't cause any particular harm to anyone testing which one is better overall.

It is unfair if one of the medicines do not have as much of an effect than the other one. Each participant should have equal treatment; however, it is more beneficial in the long run to see which drug has more benefits so that the doctor can use this drug more in the future.

I'm not sure how I feel about the ethics of doctors running experiments on their patients like this, but don't projects like this require a placebo Control group? Isn't that important for accurate and scientific results?

He is using his patients as test subjects without their consent. The test does not control for circumstances that might affect blood pressure other than the medicine. The test does not use a random sample. The doctor is going to rely on the results of the test to give all future patients identical treatment instead of determining the best treatment for each individual based on their unique attributes and circumstances.
It seems like a good idea, but he has no control group to see if there is an effect, and no informed consent from his patients, which is unethical.
He should be informing his patients that they are participating in the experiment.
I think it's in appropriate to run experiments on his patients without informing them ahead of time

If both of the treatments seem to be equal, I think this would be okay so that he can gather more information and see the results of the two drugs himself, thereby enabling him to make a  more informed decision for his patients in the future.
Unless he tells the patients that there is a possibility the drugs won't work, it's not a good thing to do. Some people will be expecting relief from their symptoms or a cure.

It sounds like the side effects are minimal and similar, when several drugs were approved it would be best to test more than one to see what works best. I thinks it is appropriate to test out more than one drug for effectiveness and side effects.
He is basically experimenting on his patients.  I think this is unethical and you shouldn't use people for experiments.

I have no idea on the ethics on this. There are so many variables that make one medicine work better than the other. If according to studies the medicines are completely even, it's the best way for the doctor to make his own decision on what to prescribe.
He should have chose people who had high blood pressure.
Both drugs were approved by USFDA, so I found dr.Jhones decision is very appropiate

It's appropriate in the sense that it helps them better understand which drug is more effective, but since they wouldn't be changing the less effective prescription afterward, it's kind of bad for that test group.
I feel it's very inappropriate because it seems as if the patients themselves are not aware of the doctor's experiment, which would be an unethical action on the doctor's part.
The FDA has already approved the drugs. He should discuss the options with each patient and decide together.
He needs to find what medication works best, and the side affects are manageable.
It is not fair to the other half of patients. If the medicine worked for the other half, the doctor will not prescribe it to them.

I'm not sure but I don't think he should be doing an experiment without the patients giving consent to sign up for the experiment.  It also weird because if the FDA approved the drug it seems like there should be already studies done that he can look at instead of doing an experiment by himself.

It's a personal clinical trial without any oversight or controls, and if he doesn't inform the participants they're in a trial he should be struck off. But if they are informed and willing, no real reason he shouldn't do it.
He is doing a long term test, and will then prescribe the med that has the best results.  That is good.
I do not feel that it is Doctor Jones is able to experiment like that. I thought that studies had to be taken. Also each person has their own needs.

A walk in clinic is not a place for experiments. A doctor must do what is best for the patient. Studies that analyze the effectiveness of drugs should be carried out in an official setting and have people making sure the study is following ethical rules and so on.

I chose this because I think that trying to figure out which pill to prescribe I would want to prescribe the one that is more effective. I also feel that they could get samples to distribute to the patients if they chose one as their go to medicine.
Since both drugs were approved by FDA, it means they are both safe, so there's nothing wrong with the doctor's decision.
You could possibly could harm the patients.  I believe leave it to the scientist to test
because he doesn't know which is best but both are approves so hes not endangering his patients in any way
I am not sure if there are legal restrictions on his action. Alone, it is a valid way to prescribe drugs. Or a doctor could just randomly prescribe different drugs.
I think it is appropriate to try this experiment, though there is some risk involved by randomly giving drugs to random patients without checking their history first. It can cause negligence.
I think it's a bit unprofessional to use chance as a way to treat your patients, and I don't think all of his patients would approve of what he's doing.
I think that is a reasonable experiment to run, assuming the side effects are about equal. That way he has his own data to make a call.
He is experimenting on people without their consent and that doesn't seem like it's appropriate to do. If people were informed I would think it was a better idea.

Doctor Jones should be prescribing the medications based on how well they meet the patients' needs. It's inappropriate to conduct an experiment on patients like this, even if the drugs are considered safe. They're expecting treatment for their high blood pressure, not to be quietly treated like lab rats.
Dr. Jones shouldn't be performing this experiment himself. This should be done in a lab under stricter test requirements. There are too many variables unaccounted for.
Because in the end he will get the best results because he is finding out what is best for his patience.  Good thought

Drugs approved by the FDA are not always as effective as they are stated to be by the drug companies. The doctor is trying to provide the best care for his patients and he his not withholding treatment or doing anything unethical.
Being he is a doctor I think it is ok to experiment provided that he want to make sure the patients get the best drug.
If the medicines are comparable in price and tolerance, why not check to see if one is more effective than another?
I think it's a good idea to test both drugs to find which one performs better but I do think that the patients should know that they are part of an experiment.
both drugs are possible treatment options, and thus both are valid choices. his decision is fine, and prescribing the best outcomes as a result of that is even better.

This is inappropriate because the doctor could be biased.  He could provide patients that he likes the drug that he feels has advantages. He could give patients that he dislikes the other drug.  Scientific research should be done in the lab, not in the office.
I believe people should be aware they are part of a test. They need to give their consent.
He randomly assigned the drug without asking patients if they are okay with it. It would be more appropriate if he asked them for consent.
It's not right to test medications on people unless they give there consent

The doctor is not sure of which is better so he is going to use personal experience to test the results. Instead of relying on clinical data he will use real world input. This will give a more grounded results based evidence that isnt paid for or marketed towards him.
Both drugs seem to have similar effects. I sad it's somewhat appropriate what Jones did.
He misled customers to believe they were getting the best medicine.

If both options are affordable and well tolerated by patients, then either option would likely be beneficial to most payments.  However, Dr. Jones' approach does not take into account the differences between patients.
for one reason not all patients are his only

Based on the fact that "both drugs are affordable and patients can tolerate their side effects", there doesn't seem to be any ethical fallacy in prescribing one drug over the other. It makes sense to see which drug is actually more effective.
Does not seem ethical to offer one thing to one group of people and a better offer to a second group.
I would give all employees the same opportunity for retirement. If that meant that I had to run two different tests at two different times, then so be it.

The CEO isn't harming anyone by doing this, and encouraging people to save is a good thing. The only downside is the fact that half of the new hires have an additional five stocks to pick from, some of which might be better.
Because the company just need to explain all of the benefits of the retirements plans and then the new hires need to make their own decisions.
Because he is treating similar level employees differently.
I feel that his experiment does nothing to influence employees to increase their rate of using the company plan. Offering more options does nothing in my opinion.

good survey

He is bargaining with people's retirement savings. He should offer both choices to both groups.
They should all have the same choices.  This is not something you experiment with.
I think that both of the groups should have the same investment funds to choose from.
I just think it should be uniform. Employees want fair options across the board.

employees will be happily retired

he's using resources to do an experiment on retirement plans without telling the company executives.

Personally, I don't think the alternatives will make much difference.

every hospital is different and have a different program for the residency, so it's best for individual hospital to chose the policy that works best for them.
because either way you loose. Either no sleep or no education.

I did not know about such restrictions before reading this.  The arguments for shorter hours makes sense and so does the argument for longer hours.  I am concerned that any patient should be affected at all by a mistake that one of their policies influence. this is appropriate because it will benefit the patients
This is a very important decision that affects the lives of the patients. This decision should not be taken lightly but should be made given the findings.

The accrediting body is working under the assumption that patient welfare is what is most important. Therefore, they should be allowed to consider whatever choice is best suited for the patients in the hospital.
I've never worked in, or had extensive exposure to health care systems. My opinion in this matter is not based on a reasonable level of knowledge.
While I think the hours are absurd, I think it's a good mechanism for testing the theory. In the end, they'll be able to look at a variety of results to see which is best.
there are important reasons to both sides and a happy medium needs to be discovered and implemented.

they need to have details themselves that a difference in work limits have direct impacts on patient care. It is a difficult study, but i see the importance in the decision to test performance.  Doctors & those training to be, deserve to work appropriate hours.  in my view 16 hour days are beyond anyone's ability to perform at the highest level.
The experiment seems like it would find the best practices for residents.

The accrediting body wants to give the hospitals some autonomy (which is appropriate). However, I would be concerned that some hospitals would pick longer shifts just so they can have more bodies in the hospital.
If the decision results in less competant doctos I feel it's innapropriate

The accrediting body allows the hospitals to adopt the appropriate working hours based on their own systems. This is good as the hospitals have more flexibility. The first year residents can also decide on which hospital to join based on their preferences on working hours.
I can't think of any reason why it would be inappropriate. It's the accrediting body's prerogative.

I think patient safety should be a hospital's priority. While hospitals do need to subject their residents to the rigors of medical work, it should not be done to an extent where it harms patient outcome.

It appears that first year resident students will be required to do lengthy hours. I believe that requiring the resident students to do such lengthy hours is unhealthy and and not practical for the healthcare of the patients.

because people need to be well rested to continue putting out exceptional work. It doesnt matter if the person thinks they can handle a bigger workload, they have it scheduled that way for a reason. The body and mind need to rest.
It makes sense to try both approaches. You can debate the merits of either idea, but you'll never know until you put it into action.
This seems to make sense to me, although I've never thought about theses issues before.

I think they are trying to see which policy works better and will probably adopt one over the other depending on how well the new doctors do under each policy. It sounds like it may work, but I think it would be more consistent and professional if they just stuck to one policy for all new doctors.

I see the wisdom in both sides of this experiment, and I don't know myself what option is right.  However, I understand that the beneficiaries of this study would be patients, and this decision is designed with their best interest in mind.  If I was hospitalized, or if it were members of my family, I'd want them to get the best health care possible.
It is the best decision for this situation. I completely agree.
It seems to me they are trying to figure out the best schedules to be most effective for patients and residents.
It is using scientific method
There has to be another way to help citizens find a job. Handing out money is not the solution.
I would choose the $500 a month option.  I would try very hard to obtain employment, and would tend to believe I could find it relatively soon, and therefore make wages plus the $500 for some time.
It unfairly gives half of the unemployed reduced benefits.  The congress should apply a benefit fairly and evenly to all of those who qualify.

I believe this will create incentive for some people to not try to look for work due to the easy money given. I think the people getting money will grow depended on the money and will find a way to avoid working.

I support Universal Basic Income programs to stimulate wages, and this is a step towards that sort of a program. This stimulates the national economy, boosting the need for more jobs, which will gives these unemployed workers more opportunities to become employed.
Both programs will benefit the unemployed. It also gives the government the advantage of which program will be more effective.

The government is paying citizens to be unemployed. Those who are receiving more money might delay their employment to reap full benefits and the total promised amount of money from this study. The incentive might change from finding a job to getting the money promised if unemployment continues.
Congress should not be using tax payer money to pay those who are unemployed, even for a short amount of time. This can lead to a GREAT deal of fraud.
Funding for this support is not feasible if the budget is strained.  I might approve of such support if campaign finance contributions are taxed to keep the budget balanced.

I do not understand how the congress can afford to spend all that money to people that are not working.  It seems as though either group would not try to find a job until after the payments had stopped.  I believe the money would be better spent educating the unemployed so they have skills to find jobs.  The congress should also help businesses create more jobs.
It doesn't seem fair for them to get money even if they have a job.
Because it's an unknown experiment, so it's okay to try once, and see what happens. However, it could have a bad or a good outcome.

I think it would be interesting to see how the results work out,because I could see both options being beneficial. Whichever does work out, would be a great way for the government to function from then on.
Once the person finds work, benefits should end.

I think that the intention of the congress to motivate unemployed people is very appropriate. Since it sees unemployment as a problem for its economy, I think it is good that it is testing potential solutions.

I believe this to be a somewhat inappropriate decision because both systems could rather easily be abused and both only provide some kind of support for half the year. A system that would be harder to qualify for but was more consistently supportive would work better in my opinion.

Not knowing the size of the population, I am uncertain how their method strives to motivate their citizens to seek out jobs. In the first option, citizens can wait 5 months before beginning to look for a job so as to maximize their earnings from the $1000/month six month period. In the second, it would serve more as a bonus rather than a driving incentive.

In a way it is fair but in a way it is unfair. If the government wants to do that then they need to come up with a way to pay citizens equally or at least close to equally if they all have to attend the monthly job fairs.

I selected somewhat inappropriate because there will be a large amount of people during the test that are going 6 months with the worse plan of the two plans being tested. The people should be able to select which plan they want to be tested on.
I just went with my gut.
It doesn't seem inappropriate. It seems like an alright idea to help people out who are struggling. Also, the job fairs could help workers find a new job.
It encourages people to find a job, while helping them with present needs.

It would seem possibly problematic to have two different groups of people taking on two different types of benefits. Random assignment would be the most scientific but also the least equitable. It would give the government some data to rely on, but also possible cause a rift between the two groups, so I chose somewhat appropriate.
I think that it would be a good gauge to see which system would be better.  If one produces lower unemployment, that would be the choice
It shows the congress is very concerned about the well being of the people.

I think both solutions have potential, and experimenting with both of them should show which is a better system - that's the appropriate part.  The somewhat choice is because I'm unsure how ethical it is to conduct an experiment on your populace.

It encourages citizens to try to find a job. If they choose the $500, they will receive $3000 even if they find a job. If they choose the $1000, they could receive less or more money, depending on when or if they find a job. In either case, they are required to attend monthly job fairs, so they would have the opportunity to find a job if one is available.

People who are out of work may still have families and the need to support them. By still giving 500 dollars a month to people who find a job, they may have a chance to get out of debt and have incentive to stay employed. The other half won't have as much incentive to find work, but they will have quite a bit of dough to keep food on the table.
It isn't easy finding work with a lot of companies hiring people outside the county. Sometimes people just need help to get by.
both ranges fall within the best level
It may seem somewhat inhumane but if they already know that both options of levels are safe I dont see the harm. It may be the fastest way to perform the study as well.

If the babies will quite possibly die in the hospital anyhow, it could be viewed as a worthwhile cause to do such experiments. The goal obviously will be able to save more premature babies in the future with the information learned from this experiment. Without any detailed explanation, the head of the hospital's decision seems cold and cruel. But if the long term plan results in a higher survival rate, it may be for the best.
He was doing his best with the information he had at the time.
Both groups are within the accepted range so no harm will be done.

It seems morally wrong to experiment of living human babies like that. Also no where in that paragraph did it mention that the head of hospital unit is receiving permission from the parents of the children to conduct this study.

While the hospital unit head's decision is supposed to be in the best interest of treating babies, he does not acquire informed consent from the babies' parents about the treatment that they will be undergoing.

Because these babies are real people and shouldn't be used as a test object. It doesn't sound morally right. I would think we should be able to use some other creature close to humans to test this out on. Rats are commonly used.

I feel that this is a good way to test the appropriate level to support the baby without giving it too much or more than it needs. However, there could be a lot of babies that die because of the test. 1 year is a long time.
because it doesnt seem like the received consent from the parents, and it seems like theres a more ethical way to conduct the experiment.

The head doctor don't know what the optimum number is. So this is probably the best way to zoom in on the number which gives the highest survival. Another way is to closely monitor each and every baby's progress closely and adjust levels accordingly.

If it is unknown which oxygen amount is better for the children, and if neither of those oxygen amount hurts the children, this would be a very helpful experiment for future children who would also need this treatment.
I understand that the data would be important and has to be gathered somehow, but this seems the wrong way to go about it, potentially harming half of the babies.
The values are within the known acceptable range, so why not try and pinpoint? It should be a non-issue that ultimately helps improve practices in the future.
Both ranges are within the safe zone. The doctor is trying to help the infants.
Seems like he's risking half of the babies' lives more than the other half.

I'm assuming that there are no ways for the doctors to look up this information or otherwise find out. Therefore, it's appropriate because the doctors are still putting the babies in the appropriate range. They are just narrowing it down to an even better range. It would be no different from a clinical trial with patients taking different types of drugs to determine the best one. Sometimes this is simply necessary to advance medicine.

While I can understand the goal of what he is attempting, and I can see that he has good intentions, it is highly unethical to experiment like this. It is especially inappropriate because he is counting on the deaths of babies to determine the results.
t's not moral to do an experiment like that. Especially not up to him.

I think this is not very scientific, but given the resources the hospital has, it makes sense to do a pseudo-study to see what oxygen levels may be best. At least they are checking instead of pondering the whole time and guessing.
I'm kind of conflicted about this.  On one hand I don't like the idea of the babies being used for an experiment.  On the other hand maybe its good to prevent future deaths.
He is not endangering any lives.  The doctor is keeping the level at an acceptable rate for all.
It would be okay if the parents knew about it and agreed to it. If they don't know about it, this would be unethical.
The conclusions of this study will help future babies, no babies will be given a saturation level outside the acceptable range, and the risks to each control group are presumably equal.

Although the doctor's intentions are good in the longterm, he cannot perform any experiment on human's without their knowledge and permission, or their guardian's. The outcome may be positive, but the means to get there is not okay, especially when human lives are at risk.
Cause they're messing with human life and know the consequences.

Needs to get data somehow.  And this is not deliberately harming anyone.  If he gets initial data strongly one way or the other, it might be better to shorten the test and switch all to the superior treatment option.

He is more likely to correctly determine the ideal oxygen level and save more babies in the long run than arbitrarily continuing to choose a level between 85-95%.  There is no more risk involved to the babies being assigned a certain level than if a level was chosen arbitrarily.
Tough to do these types of experiments as it can hurt/kill some of the test subjects involved but in the long term may identify what can be life saving.

I chose the option I chose because this question of testing of a scientific theory boils down to ethics. It is unethical to use human newborns as test subjects in this scenario. The action of basically experimenting with getting applicants for a needed, important job is kind of worrying. This type of job should be done by people who are skilled and caring enough. To only emphasize that it could be a way to gain social respect or a better career is not a great idea.
While both options may prove beneficial, it feels somewhat like an experiment that is being done without the consent of the target group.

I would like to see the nation recruit via a combination of both the social and career benefits of becoming a Health Assistant.  I feel that the true and honest nature of recruiting will bring a group of high-quality, career focused people who would be committed to the Health Assistant position on the basis of both social and professional aspirations.
I think this a very innovative way of addressing healtcare and the shortages throughout the area
People are attracted to opportunities for different reasons.

I think its a great way to get people to think about becoming a health aide. I like the poster with the career benefits because at the end of the day, people need to be paid for their hard work. This will be enticing.

I think this method of testing should not be at the expense of people's lives.  If the candidate does not have the credentials to serve the public, they should not have the "opportunity" to do so.  The candidate should already have the training and skills prior to fulfilling the role.
It's a good way to help those in need by creating something specifically for that need.
I think it's fair to use this test as for research purposes. It will show how people react to the different types of advertising for this profession.
I think both ways will attract some good people. It is a interesting way to test out  which way is the more efficient.
It's appropriate to determine which part of the job and how it's advertised works best to pull qualified applicants to apply for the position.
Either is a valid way to draw applicants.  Either way will attract people who are serious about the role, even if for possibly different reasons.
They are doing what they can to get people to work as Health Assistants. There is nothing illegal about seeing which poster brings in more people. It is an experiment.

I believe that they should both be the same, as they are for the same country, and you want someone that is working in health to be focused on the impact that they can have on peoples lives and not the career benefits.
I don't see anything wrong with using posters that attract the best candidates for the job. All organizations want the best candidates and this shouldn't be any different.
The choices for candidates shouldn't be based on responses to posters. Candidates should be evaluated on some kind of test.
I don't see any issue with this approach.  Whatever they need to do to get people trained, it seems harmless and no different then watching commercials or reading advertisements.
Advertising to touch a person's social benefits rather than just career benefits is somewhat more appropriate because it focuses on the greater good.
It seems that the study is not harmful and could be useful in the future for figuring out how to best effectively market training programs.
I think that getting a colonoscopy at that age can help catch things that could save your life. Setting up an appointment should encourage people to follow through.
Neither idea is personally invasive and both have the best interests of the patients at heart.

I think some might be offended and not do the test all together.   I think the best thing would be to find a bit more pleasant of a prep!  That is the worst part.   I barely could finish mine because it made me sick.  Thankfully the pharmacist suggested drinking broth before each swig of the prep.

It's a good idea that the director is encouraging people to get colonoscopies but how appropriate their methods are depends on how the patients react to the different methods. That's why I chose neither appropriate or inappropriate.
It might get more people to get colonoscopies by providing them with an item or a service.  People like free stuff.
Because it does seem like both could work and make it less intimidating. I just don't know if everyone would appreciate it and feel well about it, so I chose somewhat appropriate.
I think the scheduling option is very appropriate, but the idea of sending out crossword puzzles is inappropriate.
It seems like the medical director is kind of tricking the patients into getting a colonoscopy, which the patient most likely doesn't want even though its beneficial for them.
This takes away people's agency.
it promotes screening So, it's a good thing.
It's true. Who wants to do this? It adds a little lightness and humor to a serious need to have these done but for some people, this may nudge but may not be enough to get them to do it anyhow.

The first idea is good because it's not obtrusive.  The second idea of pre-screening is obtrusive and some might find it annoying.  No doubt, the half receiving an appointment without setting it up will be calling them to cancel or scream causing them a customer service nightmare.  Bad idea.
I found the procedure to be completely normal.

I think its weird and would be embarrassing, i also think they shouldnt be charged anyways if they dont show up. I think people should still have the choice to do it on their own and not have the doctor intervene into your personal business.

This is not inappropriate because the medical doctor is just trying to create awareness for getting routine colonoscopies. I feel this is a good method to bring more people into the office to get there procedures done as their lives could depend on it.
I think scheduling an appointment for someone is a bit out of line, even if they aren't required to keep the appointment. It puts a burden on them.
I didn't find anything offensive to me. Maybe some other people are sensitive and will find it inappropriate.
I felt at least some patients will turn up when you give some options

I think it makes sense to do a randomized control trial to see which method works better, although it should be ideally based in research and all variables should be controlled in order to get actual accurate results
preventive medicine is vital

It is important that people receive proper preventative health care. This saves everyone money in the long term. If there is anything that doctor's can do to increase preventative health screening they should do them.

The medical director is thinking outside the box to help his patients. It's an unconventional idea, however it does help people to think to start the motion. Also a good reminder since most people would avoid it if not prompt at the right time.
I love the idea of using comedy to get people to take care of themselves.
Leading more patients to have colonoscopies is a  weird choice.
Most people won't do a procedure like this without a little nudging.  I think this is the perfect amount of nudge to get people in to get tested.
I think it's inappropriate to schedule people for appointments without asking them.  I agree that scheduling appointments is a pain, but so is calling to reschedule.
because it was a creative way to get people to check on their health
I don't like to reminded of terrible things on the day of my birthdya.

I think this is a sensible experiment to run. But he should get it evaluated by other medical staff and experts. Maybe consider giving everybody both a pre-schedule appointment and a packet with coupons since nobody will miss out on a very important procedure. Having people miss out isn't technically his responsibility, but it would still be better.

I would select the other half option, as it would be a pre-scheduled colonoscopy appointment, with the option to select the time and if a problem came up and I were to miss the appointment I won‰Ûªt be charged.

This just seems very intrusive and forced. If a person is THAT interested in such a procedure, they will go about it at their own accord. There are dozens of other ways to increase colon cancer/colonoscopy awareness.
I think it would be better to try both over a separate year if you really wanted to try both.
It sounds like they are trying to find a method to motivate the teachers to perform better through offering rewards. I see no reason to dislike the idea.

Well i think it's somewhat appropriate because in this scenario the teachers were going to benefit regardless. They're also running an experiment and not just deciding which will work better but actually trying 2 different things.
You cannot compare schools or classrooms since demographics of schools and classrooms differ so vastly.
I think he is trying to be fair with giving the teachers what they want.
I like the idea because I believe a teacher will strive for better results if an extra reward is offered.
It's up to him to decide what is best and what works.
He could have just asked the teachers which they would prefer the most.  Most importantly there is no control group.
it may work if people want different things

I chose my reason because incentives can motivate teachers to perform better and motivate students. Yet, the different types of incentives can cause division and uncertainty especially if the teachers can't choose which incentive they'd like to receive.
The motivation structure is not equal. The people getting vacation time will feel as if they are getting less of an incentive.
I think the intention is good and there is no real harm done in the process of what he's doing but it does lack transparency with the teachers being subject to the study
The superintendent wants to improve their students progress.  So, I think is a good idea to do this exercise to discover, how can they help.

It is not a terribly scientific study.  Also, he promises half of the teachers one benefit and then gives them something else, since he gives all of them the same benefit in the end.  And how is "better student outcomes" defined.

I think it is only somewhat appropriate because the superintendent should instead do a survey of teachers' preferences, that way he or she can then make a better decision in assigning either the bonus or vacation time to teachers.
Segregation of rewards is not morale, and the ends might not justify the means.
The superintendent is testing different systems, and I guess that's good. However, a better option would be to let the teachers choose. That way there would be more incentive to succeed.
Because it is a test to see who will do better and both are receiving benefits from it.
It seems like it would work, but also there are a lot of uncontrolled variables.

I don't think there is anything wrong with randomly assigning the teachers to the two favorable conditions. If the superintendent purposely assigned individuals to the 2 categories, then his actions could be inappropriate.
Because it does not really have the students best interests in my mind.
I think that there is too much dependant on the teachers while you can't really control who your students are that year and how they behave/learn in the classroom.
those are two wildly different things.  you can't play with people like that even if it's a trial basis
I think it is wise to conduct the experiment but the teachers should be given the choice of which option they would prefer.
I don't see anything wrong with the tests. I'm not confident of how effective it will be, but it seems like a great idea.
It seems like he is doing it for the right reasons and he is trying to be unbiased in his decision.
It seems like a fair incentive for teachers to earn a reward based on performance.   Performance based rewards often result in positive outcomes.

I think it is inappropriate because the superintendent is choosing for the teachers. Some who got extra vacation days may have wanted the bonus and vice versa, therefore some may be hindered by his actions.

It doesn‰Ûªt sound fair payment-wise to the teachers. The experiment is flawed because not only would it take a year to complete but also only one group of people will receive money while the other group, who may work just as hard, doesn‰Ûªt get extra money at all only extra vacation days without money to use for those days.
I think if the teacher is happy and not burnt out or stressed their teaching habits will be better.
Teachers shouldn't have to be given such perks to be happy at their jobs. If that was the case then maybe they shouldn't be teachers.
It is his job to decide how to best combat poverty using welfare. This is simply finding the most effective way to deal with poverty.
It seems unfair to use peoples lives as an experiments, especially without their knowledge.
I think it could be a good idea to experiment with different methods to see what works.

I think this department head is willing to invest in the long run towards a proven record of success. It may not bring instant relief to both counties equally, but the strategy would produce benefits in the long run. A well-researched, successful approach takes time. The only hang up in this case is that there are more dependent variables in the second county than in the first that might throw off the experiment.
This is a horrible way to conduct an "experiment". Using his citizens as lab rats is a horrible thing to do.
Neither option seems to be harmful and it would be a good way to see which option is better
it is giving people with no chance of succeeding. if it works then more people will get jobs and get off welfare, if it doesn't work at least the people below the poverty line get a chance.
It is important to test out different methods for solving social problems. By testing different methods the director could possibly find a better solution to their mission.
He is actually doing something about the issue and testing to see which way will help the most.

The way to reduce poverty and unemployment is to inspire people to produce.  Increasing welfare never does that.  When Bill Clinton added the work requirement to welfare back in the '90s, on average, people's lives improved and poverty and unemployment were reduced.  No need to experiment - the work has already been done - we know what to do.

I believe it is somewhat appropriate because he is trying to find out the best way to go about a problem. Sometimes the only way to test something is in real world situations. The test will only go on for a year and everyone is still getting the help the need, just some more than others.
It sounds reasonable to try out. However, I do not think increasing welfare will reduce poverty.
I think it is inappropriate to treat people who depend on your policies as test subjects without their input
Those people that aren't receiving the higher benefits will have to make do for a year while the experiment plays out.  This could cause significant hardship.
He does not have the authority to make a decision over the lives of people base on his ideas.
HE SHOULD INCREASE OR DECREASE WELFARE SERVICES EQUALLY.
The state is using research to determine the best way to deploy taxpayers funds.

I believe that the experiment would most likely show that a moderate increase to welfare services equally would yield the most favorable results. There would need to be information provided about the poverty line to determine how appropriate the decision is.
He tried to be fair about it.  He did experiments to see which would work
The poorest families need the most help.
It seems like a fair way to determine the best way to allocate resources. I think it's one of the easier ways to finding the most effective solution.
It doesn't seem fair to randomly select who gets more welfare. It should go to whomever needs it the most.

I think it is somewhat inappropriate because I don't think the results of the method are a good indicator of what is going to work. There are different variables and the counties are not the same across the board, like income, racial make up, job opportunities, etc.  So that is why I think it is inappropriate.
I THINK IT IS A REASONABLE TEST. THIS WAY, THEY CAN GET A GOOD CONTROL GROUP AND LEARN FROM THIS.  I THINK IT IS FAIR.

I like the idea of testing which works better, but, it does run the Rik of hurting some people if one of them is less effective than the other. Generally for testing if people may suffer you can't test it. But I'm not an ethical committee member and I recommend such a group review this idea first
The aid is spread out to the poorest families. The aid is not equal but it will be down the road.

I think that the head of the department has the right idea because he is trying to find the best fix for the issue of unemployment.  Currently he is going to try two different paths and pick the one that works the best.  Along with the fact that money isn't being taken away from anyone.
Well, you have to try various ways of doing things to see if they work, so if all things are as equal as possible between the counties chosen, I see no problem with this method.
This experiment could hurt the poor people. Experiment should not done with the lives of poor people.
I think there should always be research and facts based around such a drastic study. People should always know when they are a part of a study also.
It could be a good social experiment but everyone deserves welfare if they need it
